The Last of Us 2 represents how games sh: Having read a lot of reviews for this game; I think some people need to remember that it is\, after all\, only a video game. Admittedly it’s the sequel to a masterfully made original\, but still not of earth shattering importance. It’s not a “0” nor is it a “10”. I believe it is a good enjoyable game but not as excellent as the original. This is a common phenomenon. With the possible exception of The Godfather Part 2\, how often is the sequel not as good as the original masterpiece?I have been wracking my brain to try and work out what exactly is wrong with this sequel. I think the main issue is the disconnect between the actual gameplay and the story concepts. The game play glorifies murder. For example\, there are no non lethal  takedown\, no ability to avoid conflict with all the uninfected enemies and some extremely brutal death animations. This is not a criticism as many video games do the same thing. I for one really enjoyed the virtual blood bath that makes up the majority of the game! However\, many of the cut scenes and story concepts try and portray the opposite by Illustrating the negative side of violence and revenge. During such cut scenes\, I found myself thinking “yeah\, yeah - when can I get back to the slaughtering?” The actions of Abby and Ellie during some of the cut scenes just did not ring true. They seemed dishonest as if the characters are pretending to be sickened by the violence but can’t wait to get back to the murdering. I think this creates too much of a disconnect and does not make the characters believable or relatable.In addition\, efforts made  to expound the story concepts and explain all the character arcs made the game over long. I felt it should have ended sooner\, perhaps when Abby let’s Ellie go after the fight in the theatre.Having said all that\, it’s still an enjoyable\, action packed and excellently animated experience.… Expand
